eng_pos_or_descriptor: Southern Ndebele (English: /ɛndəˈbiːliː/), also known as Transvaal Ndebele, isiNdebele, Ndebele or South Ndebele, is an African language belonging to the Nguni group of Bantu languages, spoken by the Ndebele people of South Africa. There is also another language called Northern Ndebele, or Matabele, spoken in Zimbabwe, which is closer to Zulu than other Nguni dialects (Wikipedia)
sot_pos_or_descriptor: Sendebele Borwa ( Senyesemane : /ɛndəˈbiːliː/); se tsejwa ka hore ke Sendebele sa Transefala, Sendebele kapa Sendebele sa Borwa, ke puo ya maAforika ba leng sehlopheng sa Nguni sa dipuo tsa Bantu, se buuwang ke Mandebele a Aforika Borwa. Hape ho na le puo e nngwe e bitswang Sendebele sa Leboya, kapa Matebele, se buuwang Zimbabwe, se haufi le Sezulu ho e na le dipuwana  tse ding tsa Nguni
sot_pos_or_descriptor_info: Sendebele ke e nngwe ya dipuo tsa sehlopha sa Nguni
ssw_pos_or_descriptor: Lulwimi lwaseNingizimu Afrika lolukhulunywa eMpumalanga , Sikhona futsi Sindebele lesikhulunywa eZimbabwe.
ven_pos_or_descriptor: Nyambotavhi dza Tshindevhele.
tsn_pos_or_descriptor: SeNdebele sa Borwa, se se itsiweng gape isiNdebele, Ndebele kgotsa Ndebele ya Bokone, ke puo ya SeAforika ya dipuo tsa setlhopha sa Nguni tse di buiwang ke batho ba Aforika Borwa. Go na gape le puo e nngwe e e bidiwang Ndebele ya Bokone, kgotsa Matabele, e e buiwang kwa Zimbabwe, e e atametseng SeZulu go gaisa ditengwana tse dingwe tsa Nguni. Batho ba le bantsi ba ba buang SeNdebele sa Bokone ba nna kwa porofenseng ya Limpopo le tikologo ya yona.
tsn_pos_or_descriptor_info: SeNdebele se buiwa kwa dinageng di le pedi tsa Borwa jwa Aforika e leng Zimbabwe le Aforika Borwa

xho_pos_or_descriptor: iilwimi zesiNguni  ziliqela eliyinxenye yeelwimi zesiNtu ezithethwa eAfrika eseMzantsi ngabeNguni. Iilwimi zesiNguni ziquka isiXhosa, isiZulu, Siswati, isiHlubi, isiPhuthi, isiBhaca, isiLala, isiNhlangwini kunye neelwimi and the three languages called Ndebele: Southern Transvaal Ndebele, Zimbabwean Ndebele and Sumayela Ndebele (the last two sometimes referred to as "Northern Ndebele"). The appellation "Nguni" derives from the Nguni cattle type. Ngoni (see below) is an older, or a shifted, variant. It is sometimes argued that use of Nguni as a generic label suggests a historical monolithic unity of the peoples in question, where in fact the situation may have been more complex. The linguistic use of the label (referring to a subgrouping of Bantu) is relatively stable. (Wikipedia)

eng_pos_or_descriptor: the Nguni languages are a group of Bantu languages spoken in southern Africa by the Nguni people. Nguni languages include Xhosa, Zulu, Swati, Hlubi, Phuthi, Bhaca, Lala, Nhlangwini and the three languages called Ndebele: Southern Transvaal Ndebele, Zimbabwean Ndebele and Sumayela Ndebele (the last two sometimes referred to as "Northern Ndebele"). The appellation "Nguni" derives from the Nguni cattle type. Ngoni (see below) is an older, or a shifted, variant. It is sometimes argued that use of Nguni as a generic label suggests a historical monolithic unity of the peoples in question, where in fact the situation may have been more complex. The linguistic use of the label (referring to a subgrouping of Bantu) is relatively stable. (Wikipedia)

eng_pos_or_descriptor: Sesotho (or Sotho (/ˈsuːtuː/); also known as Southern Sotho or Southern Sesotho[5]) is a Southern Bantu language of the Sotho-Tswana (S.30) group, spoken primarily in South Africa, where it is one of the 11 official languages, and in Lesotho, where it is the national language. Like all Bantu languages, Sesotho is an agglutinative language, which uses numerous affixes and derivational and inflexional rules to build complete words (Wikipedia)
sot_pos_or_descriptor: /ˈsuːtuː/ / S.30 / <Sesotho (kapa Sotho ; hape se tsejwa ka Sesotho sa Borwa kapa Sesotho sa Borwa[5] ke Puo ya Bantu ya Borwa ya Sesotho- sehlopha sa Setswana , se buuwang haholo Afrika Borwa, moo e leng e nngwe ya dipuo tsa semmuso, hape le Lesotho. Moo e leng puo ya setjhaba. Jwalo ka dipuo tsohle tsa Bantu, Sesotho ke puo ya aklunatifi, e sebedisang dihlomathiso tse mmalwa le dikatoloso tsa leetsi le melao e rarahaneng ho ahamantswe a phethahetseng.>

tso_pos_or_descriptor: /ˈsuːtuː/ / S.30 / <Xisuthu ; nakambe ri tiveka tanihi Xisuthu xa le Dzongeni [5]) i ririmi ra ntlawa wa Vanhu va le Dzongeni wa Vasuthu-Vatswana , ri vulavuriwa ngopfu eAfrika-Dzonga, laha ri nga rin'wana ra tindzimi ta 11 ta ximfumo, na le Lesotho, laha ri nga ririmi ra rixaka. Tanihi hinkwato tindzimi ta Vantima, Xisuthu i ririmi ro namarhela, leri ri tirhisaka swinembeleto swo hlaya na swa mpfelelo na milawu ya ntlakuso wa rito ku aka marito yo hetiseka>

eng_pos_or_descriptor: The Swazi, Swati or siSwati language (Swazi: siSwati [siswatʼi]) is a Bantu language of the Nguni group spoken in Swaziland and South Africa by the Swazi people. The number of speakers is estimated to be in the region of 3 million. The language is taught in Swaziland and some South African schools in Mpumalanga, particularly former KaNgwane areas. Swazi is an official language of Swaziland (along with English), and is also one of the eleven official languages of South Africa. Although the preferred term is "Swati" among native speakers, in English it is generally referred to as Swazi. Swazi is most closely related to the other "Tekela" Nguni languages, like Phuthi and Northern Transvaal (Sumayela) Ndebele, but is also very close to the "Zunda" Nguni languages: Zulu, Southern Ndebele, Northern Ndebele, and Xhosa (Wikipedia).
sot_pos_or_descriptor: Swatsi : Seswati [seswatsi] / e tsamaya mmoho le Senyesemane / <Maswati, Seswati kapa puo ya (Seswati ke puo ya Bantu ya sehlopha sa Nguni e buuwang Eswatini le Afrika Borwa ke batho ba Maswatsi, palo ya dibui tsa puo ena e lekanyetswa ho ho batlang ho ba dimilione tse 3, puo e rutwa Eswatini le dikolong tse ding tsa Afrika Borwa Mpumalanga, ho ikgetha haholo dibakeng tsa Kangwane ya mehleng, Seswatsi ke puo ya semmuso ya Eswatini , hape ke e nngwe ya dipuo tse leshome le motso o mong tsa semmuso Afrika Borwa, le ha lereo le kgethwang e le "Seswati" hara dibui tsa matswallwa, ka Senyesemane le se le tlwaelehile ka hore ke "swazi", Swazi se amana haholo le e nngwe e bitswang "Tekela">
sot_pos_or_descriptor_info: Seswati ke e nngwe ya dipuo tsa sehlopha sa Nguni, mme se buuwa profensing ya Mpumalanga le naheng ya Eswatini

tso_pos_or_descriptor: Xiswazi kumbe ririmi ra Xiswazi  (Swazi: Xiswazi [xiswazʼi]) i ririmi ra ntlawa wa vanhu va ntlawa wa vavulavuri va Xingoni eSwazini na le Afrika-Dzonga hi Maswazi. Nhlayo ya vavulavuri vavulavuri yi kumbeteriwa ku va eka xifundza i 3 wa mamiliyioni.  Ririmi ri dyondzisiwa eswikolweni swa le Swazini na swikolweni swa Swazini na le ka swikolo swin'wana eAfrika-Dzonga eMpumalanga, ngopfungopfu ka khale ka tindhawu ta Kangwane. Xiswazi i ririmi ra ximfumo eSwazini (kun'we na Xinghezi), nakambe hi rin'wana ra tidzimi ta timfumo ta khumen'we eAfrika-Dzonga. Hambileswi theme leri va ri rhandzaka ku nga "Swati" exikarhi ka vini va ririmi, Hi Xinghezi hi ntolovelo ri tiviwa tanihi Swazi. Xiswazi xi yelana ngopfu swinene na tindzimi tin'wana ta Xingoni to "Tekela", ku fana na Phuti na Transvaal-N'walungu (Chumayela ) Xindhevele, kutani nakambe ti le kusuhi swinene eka tindzimi ta Xingoni "Zunda: Xizulu, Xindhevele xa le Dzongeni, Xindhevele xa le N'walungwini na Xiqhoza
tso_pos_or_descriptor_info: Mhani wa Misaveni i Muswazi

eng_pos_or_descriptor: Tsonga (/ˈtsɒŋɡə, ˈtsɔː-/) or Xitsonga (Tsonga: Xitsonga) is a southern African Bantu language spoken by the Tsonga people. It is mutually intelligible with Tswa and Ronga, and the name "Tsonga" is often used as a cover term for all three, also sometimes referred to as Tswa-Ronga. The Xitsonga language has been standardized for both academic and home use, making it the base language for the Tsonga people. Like with many other languages, there are various dialects within the Tsonga language group (Wikipedia)
sot_pos_or_descriptor: Setsonga (/ˈtsɒŋɡə, ˈtsɔː-/) kapa Setsonga (Tsonga Setsonga) ke puo ya Bantu ya Afrika Borwa e buuwang ke Batsonga, a ka utlwisiswa hantle le Setswana le Seronga, le lebitso"Setsonga" jwalo ka lereo le apesang tse tharo tseo tsohle, hape ka nako e nngwe le bitswa ka hore ke Setswana-Ronga, puo ya Setsonga e lokiseditswe tshebetso bakeng sa tshebediso ya ho ithuta le lapeng, ho e etsa e be puo ya motheo bakeng sa Batsonga, jwale ka dipuo tse ding, ho na le dipuwana tse fapaneng kahara sehlopha sa puo ya Setsonga

tso_pos_or_descriptor: Tsonga (/ˈtsɒŋɡə, ˈtsɔː-/)  kumbe Xitsonga (Tsonga: Xitsonga) i ririmi ra Vantima va ke Dzongeni wa Dzonga leri vulavula hi Vatsonga. Ri twisiseka hi ku tirhisana na Xitswa na Xirhonga, kasi vito ra "Tsonga" mikarhi yo tala ri tirhisiwa tanihi ku angarhela hi vunharhu hinkwato, nakambe hi mikarhi yin'wana ri vuriwa ku va ri ri tanihi Tswa-Ronga. Ririmi ra Xitsonga ri ringanisiwile ka swa dyondzo na ku tirhisiwa ekaya, ri endliwa ririmi ra masungulo ka Vatsonga. Ku fana na tindzimi tin'wana to tala, ku na marin'wana yo hambanahambana exikarhi ka ntlawa wa ririmi ra Xitsonga  Tsonga (/ˈtsɒŋɡə, ˈtsɔː-/) or Xitsonga (Tsonga: Xitsonga) is a southern African Bantu language spoken by the Tsonga people. It is mutually intelligible with Tswa and Ronga, and the name "Tsonga" is often used as a cover term for all three, also sometimes referred to as Tswa-Ronga. The Xitsonga language has been standardized for both academic and home use, making it the base language for the Tsonga people. Like with many other languages, there are various dialects within the Tsonga language group (Wikipedia)

eng_pos_or_descriptor: Tswana is an official language and lingua franca of Botswana. The majority of Tswana-speakers are found in the north of South Africa, where four million people speak the language and an urbanised variety which is part slang and not the formal Setswana, known as Pretoria Tswana, is the principal language of that city. The three South African provinces with the most speakers are Gauteng (circa 11%) and Northern cape and North West (over 70%). Until 1994, South African Tswana people were notionally citizens of Bophuthatswana, one of the bantustans of the apartheid regime. The Setswana language in the Northwest Province has variations in which it is spoken according to the tribes found in the Tswana culture [Bakgatla, Barolong, Bakwena, Batlhaping, Bahurutshe, Bafokeng to name a few] the written language remains the same. Although Tswana is spoken mostly in South Africa and Botswana, a small number of speakers are also found in Zimbabwe and Namibia; respectively, an unknown number of people and about 10,000 people speak the language there (Wikipedia)
sot_pos_or_descriptor: Setswana ke puo ya semmuso le puo e kopanyang dibui tse buang dipuo tse fapaneng tsa Botswana, boholo ba dibui tsa puo ya Setswana di fumanwa leboya la Afrika Borwa, moo batho ba dimilione tse nne ba buang puo le karolo e toropofaditsweng e leng karolo ya puwana e seng Setswana sa semmuso, e tsejwang ka Setswana sa Tshwane, ke puo ya sehlooho ya motsemohoholo oo diprofensi tse tharo tsa Afrika Borwa ka dibui tse ngata ka ho fetisisa ke Gauteng (circa 11%) le Kapa Leboya le Leboya Bophirima (ho feta 70%), ho fihlela ka 1994, Batswana ba Afrika Borwa ba ne ba hopolwa e le baahi ba Bophuthatswana, o mong wa metsemahae a mmuso wa kgethollo, puo ya Setswana profensing ya Leboya Bophirima e na le diphapano tseo e buuwang ka tsona ho ya ka merabe e fumanwang setsong sa Batswana [Bakgatla, Barolong, Batlhaping, Bahurutse, Bafokeng, ho bolela ba mmalwa] puo e ngotsweng e dula e tshwana, leha Setswana se buuwa haholo Afrika Borwa le Botswana, palo e nyane ya dibui e fumanwa Zimbabwe le Namibia ka ho tshwana, palo e sa tsejweng ya batho le bonyane batho ba 10,000 ba bua puo moo
sot_pos_or_descriptor_info: ke rata ho ithuta ho bua Setswana

tso_pos_or_descriptor: Xitswana i ririmi ra ximfumo na ririmintwanano ya Botswana. Vunyingi bya vavulavuri va Xitswana va kumeka en'walungwini wa Afrika-Dzonga, laha vanhu va mune wa mamiliyoni va vulavula ririmi leri na ku suka eka matikoxikaya ya tinxakaxaka ku ya emadorobeni leri nga xiphemu xa mphatlukwana naswona kungari Xitswana xa ximfumo, lexi tivekaka tanihi Xitswana xa Pitori, tanihi ririmikulu ra doroba rero. Swifundzankulu swinharhu eAfrika-Dzonga swi na vavulavuri vo tala ngopfu eGauteng (kwalomu ka 11%) na Northern Cape na North West (ku tlula 70%). Ku fika 1994, Vatswana va Afrika-Dzonga va ehleketeleriwa ku va vaakatiko va Bophutatswan, rin'wana ra matikoxikaya ra mfumo wa xihlawuhlawu.  Ririmi ra Xitswana eXifundzeninkulu xa Northwest xi na vo hambana lexi exk axona xi vulavuriwaka hi ku ya hi tinxaka leti kumekaka eka ndhavuko wa Vatswana [Bakgatla, Barolong, Bakwena, Batlhaping, Bahurutshe, Bafokeng to name a few] ririmi ro tsariwa ri tama ra ha fana. Hambiloko Xitswana xi vulavuriwa ngopfu eAfrika-Dzonga na le Botswana, nhlayo yitsongo ya vavulavuri nakambe ya kumeka eZimbabwe na Namibia; hi ku landzelelana, nhlayo ya vanhu leyi nga tivekiki naswona ya kwalomu ka 10, 000 yi vulavula ririmi  leri kwale (Wikipedia)

eng_pos_or_descriptor: Venda or Tshivenda, also known as Tshivenḓa or Luvenḓa, is a Bantu language and an official language of South Africa. It is mainly spoken by the Venda people in the northern part of South Africa's Limpopo Province, as well as by some Lemba people in Zimbabwe. The Venda language is related to Kalanga (Western Shona, different from Shona, official language of Zimbabwe) which is spoken in Botswana and Zimbabwe. During the Apartheid era of South Africa, the bantustan of Venda was set up to cover the Venda speakers of South Africa (Wikipedia)
sot_pos_or_descriptor: Venda kapa Sevenda, hape se tsejwa ka Sevenda kapa Bovenda, ke puo ya Bantu le puo ya semmuso Afika Borwa, e buuwa haholo ke batho ba Venda karolong e ka leboya , profensing ya Afrika Borwa, hape le batho ba Lemba Zimbabwe, puo ya Sevenda e amana le Kalanga (Seshona Bophirima, e fapaneng ho Seshona, puo ya semmuso ya Zimbabwe) e buuwang Botswana le Zimbabwe, nakong ya kgethollo ya Afrika Borwa, motselehae wa Bavenda o ne o entswe ho boloka dibui tsa Sevenda tsa Afrika Borwa
sot_pos_or_descriptor_info: ke rata ho ithuta puo ya Sevenda
ssw_pos_or_descriptor: Luwimi lolusemtsetfweni eningizimu Afrika lolukhulunywa  yincenye yebantfu besifundza  sase Limpopo nabase  Lemba eZimbabwe .
ven_pos_or_descriptor: Tshigwada tsha Tshivenda.
tsn_pos_or_descriptor: SeVenda, se babui ba sona ba se bitsang Tshivenḓa  ke puo ya Batho ba Bantsho ba Aforika Borwa. Se buiwa thata ke baVenda kwa karolong ya bokone ba Aforika Borwa, kwa porofenseng ya Limpopo mmogo gape le batho ba Lemba kwa Zimbabwe.
tsn_pos_or_descriptor_info: Puo ya SeVenda ba sikana le SeKalanga se se buiwang kwa Botswana le Zimbabwe
tso_pos_or_descriptor: Vhenda kumbe Xivhenda, nakambe ri tiveka tanihi Xivhenda kumbe Luvenḓa, i ririmi ra Vantima naswona i ririmi ra ximfumo ra Afrika-Dzonga ri vulavuriwa ngopfu hi Vavhenda eka xiphemu xa le n'walungwini eXifundzeni xa Afrika-Dzong, nakambe na Valemba van'wana eZimbabwe. ririmi ra Xivhenda ri yelana ni Xikalanga (Xixona xa le Vupeladyambu, xi hambana na Xixona, ririmi ra ximfumo eZimbabwe) lexi vulavuriwaka eBotswana na Zimbabwe. Hi nkarhi wa Mfumo wa Xihlawuhlawu eAfrika-Dzonga, tikoxikaya ra Vhenda a ri vekiwile leswaku ri korhokela vavulavuri va Xivhenda eAfrika-Dzonga
tso_pos_or_descriptor_info: Mulungu loyi u kota ku tsala switlhokovetselo hi Xivhenda

eng_pos_or_descriptor: Xhosa or isiXhosa (Xhosa: isiXhosa [isikǁʰɔ́ːsa]) is a Nguni Bantu language with click consonants ("Xhosa" begins with a click) and one of the official languages of South Africa. Although not widely spoken there, it is also an official language of Zimbabwe. "Xhosa is spoken as a first language by 8.2 million people and by 11 million as a second language in South Africa, mostly in Eastern Cape Province. Total number of users in all countries is 19.2 million (Ethnologue)". Like most other Bantu languages, Xhosa is a tonal language; the same sequence of consonants and vowels can have different meanings, depending on intonation. Xhosa has two tones: high and low. Xhosa is written with the Latin alphabet. Three letters are used to indicate the basic clicks: c for dental clicks, x for lateral clicks and q for post-alveolar clicks (for a more detailed explanation, see the table of consonant phonemes below). Tones are not normally indicated in writing (Wikipedia).
sot_pos_or_descriptor: isiXhosa kapa Sexhosa (Xhosa: Sexhosa [isikǁʰɔ́ːsa]) ke puo ya Nguni Bantu ka didumammoho tse tlanyang ("Sexhosa" se qala ka ho tlanya) ke e nngwe ya dipuo tsa semmuso tsa Afrika Borwa, le ha se sa buuwe ka bophara moo, e ntse e le puo ya semmuso ya Zimbabwe, "Sexhosa se buuwa jwalo ka puo ya pele ke batho ba dimilione tse 8.2 le ke dimilione tse 11 jwalo ka puo ka bobedi Afrika Borwa, haholo provensing ya Kapa Botjhabela, palokakaretso ya basebedisi dinaheng kaofela ke dimilione tse 19,2 (Ethnologue), jwalo ka boholo ba dipuo tse ding tsa Bantu, Sexhosa ke puo ya sehalo; tatelano ya yona eo ya didumammoho le didumanotshi e ka ba le meelelo e fapaneng, ho itshetlehilwe ka sehalo: Sexhosa se na le dihalo tse pedi: se hodimo le se tlase. Sexhosa se ngotswe ka alfabete ya Selatini, ditlhaku tse tharo di sebedisitswe ho  bontsha ditlanyi tsa motheo: c ditlanyi tsa meno, x ditlanyi tsa morao le q bakeng sa ditlanyi tse kamora hore leleme le kgitle meno, dihalo hangata di bontshwa ka ho ngolwa
sot_pos_or_descriptor_info: Sexhosa ke puo e sebediswang  Kapa Botjhabela, eo e leng karolo ya Nguni

tsn_pos_or_descriptor: SeXhosa ke puo e e buiwang ke batho ba Bantsho ba setlhopha MaNguni mo Aforika Borwa, ba setso le puo ya bona e leng tsa seXhosa. Bontsi ba bona bo fitlhelwa thata kwa porofenseng ya Kapa Botlhaba mme ba tletse gape kwa porofenseng ya Gauteng le kwa Zimbabwe. Palo e nngwe ya bona e e bonalang e fitlhelwa kwa porofenseng ya Kapa Bokone. Puo ya SeXhosa, ke nngwe wa dipuo tse 11 tsa semmuso tsa mo Aforika Borwa.  Puo ya SeXhosa e tletse ka medumo ya dikakato e e tlwaelegileng  mo puong ya SeKhoisan.
tsn_pos_or_descriptor_info: Nomfundo o rata go mpitsa ka puo ya gagwe ya SeXhosa a re 'Noxolo'
tso_pos_or_descriptor: Xiqhoza (Xhosa: Xiqhoza  [isikǁʰɔ́ːsa]) i ririmi ra ntlawa wa Xingoni leri nga ni switatisisi swa xintlokolo ("Xiqhoza" xi sungula hi xintlokolo) naswona hi rin'wana ra tindzimi ta ximfumo ta Afrika-Dzonga. Hambiloko ri nga vulavuriwi hi ku anama kona kwale, nakambe i ririmi ra ximfumo eZimbabwe. Xiqhoza xi vulavuriwa tanihi ririmi ra le kaya hi 8.2 wa mamiliyoni wa vanhu na hi 11 wa mamiliyoni tanihi ririmi ra vumbirhi eAfrika-Dzonga, ngopfungopfu eXifundzenikulu xa Eastern Cape. Nhlayo yo tala leyi yi xi tirhisaka ematikweni hinkwawo i 19.2 wa mamiliyoni (Ethnologue)". Ku fana ni tindzimi ta Rixaka rin'wana, Xiqhoza i ririmi leri nga helela; ku landzelelana ko fana ka switatisi na switwari swi nga ha va ni tinhlamuselo to hambana, swi ya hi vuxokoxoko. Xiqhoza xi na tithoni timbirhi: ya le henhla na ya le hansi. Xiqhoza xi tsariwa na alifabete ya Xilatini. Maletere manharhu ma tirhisiwa ku kombisa xintlokolo xa nkoka, x xa xintlokolo xa meno na q xa xintlokolo xa alivhiyola ka swintlokolo swa switatisi swo twarisiwa hi milomu (ka vuxokoxoko byo tala bya nhlamuselo, vona tafula ra tifonimi ta switatisi laha hansi). Tithoni a ti kombisiwangi eka xiyimo lexi nga tshamiseka hi ku tsala
tso_pos_or_descriptor_info: va yimbelela tinsimu ta vona hi Xighoza

xho_pos_or_descriptor: Ulwimi lwesiSwazi, isiSwati okanye siSwati  (iSwazi: siSwati [siswatʼi]) lulwimi lwesiNtu/lweBantu kwiqela leelwimi zesiNguni noluthethwa eSwaziland naseMzantsi Afrika ngabantu abangamaSwazi. Inani lezithethi zaso liqikelelwa kwizigidi ezi-3. Olu lwimi lufundiswa eSwaziland nakwezinye izikolo zaseMzantsi Afrika eMpumalanga, ngakumbi kwimimandla yaKaNgwane yethuba langaphambili. IsiSwazi silulwimi lwaseseburhulumenteni lwaseSwaziland (kunye nesiNgesi),kanti lukwalolunye lweelwimi ezilishumi elinanye zaseburhulumenteni baseMzantsi Afrika. Nangona izithethi zomthonyama zolu lwimi zikhetha ukuthi "Swati", ngolwimi lwesiNgesi kuthiwa Swazi. IsiSwazi sinxulumene kakhulu neelwimi zesiNguni "zeTekela", ezifana nesiPhuthi nesiNdebele saseMntla Transvaal (iSumayela), kodwa sisondele kakhulu kwiilwimi zesiNguni "zeZunda": isiZulu, isiNdebele saseMzantsi nesiXhosa (Wikipedia).

xho_pos_or_descriptor: isiTsonga (/ˈtsɒŋɡə, ˈtsɔː-/) okanye Xitsonga (Tsonga: Xitsonga) lulwimi lwesiNtu/lweBantu lwaseAfrika esemzantsi  oluthethwa ngabantu abangamaTsonga. Luhambelana kakuhle neTswa kunye neRonga, kanti igama elithi "Tsonga" likholisa ukuba ligama eliquka onke omathathu, kwakhona maxa wambi libhekiselele kwiTswa-Ronga. Ulwimi lweXitsonga lubekwe emgangathweni malunga nokusetyenziswa esikolweni nasekhaya, kwaza oko kwalenza lwaba lulwimi olusisiseko lwabantu bamaTsonga. Njengakwezinye iilwimi ezininzi, kukho iziyelelane ezahluka-hlukileyo zeqela leelwimi zesiTsonga (Wikipedia)

xho_pos_or_descriptor: isiTswana lulwimi lwaseburhulumenteni nolusetyenziswa njengelona liqondwa ngumntu wonke eBotswana. Uninzi lwezithethi zesiTswana zifumaneka kumntla waseMzantsi Afrika, apho abantu abazizigidi ezine bethetha olu lwimi kude kubekho nohlobo lwalo kwiindawo ezisezidolophini ezilujike lwaba luhlobo olungekho sikweni nolungesoSetswana sicwangciselweyo, olwaziwa ngokuthi sisiTswana sasePitoli, lolona lwimi luthethwa kakhulu kweso sixeko. Amaphondo amathathu aseMzantsi Afrika anezithethi ezizezona zininzi  yiGauteng (malunga ne 11%) noMntla Koloni kunye noMntla Ntshona (ngaphezu kwe 70%). Kude kube ngo-1994, abantu abangabeTswana baseMzantsi Afrika  bebe ngabemi baseBophuthatswana, enye yeendawo  yoozimelegeqe bexesha lolawuloone of the bantustans of the apartheid regime. The Setswana language in the Northwest Province has variations in which it is spoken according to the tribes found in the Tswana culture [Bakgatla, Barolong, Bakwena, Batlhaping, Bahurutshe, Bafokeng to name a few] the written language remains the same. Although Tswana is spoken mostly in South Africa and Botswana, a small number of speakers are also found in Zimbabwe and Namibia; respectively, an unknown number of people and about 10,000 people speak the language there (Wikipedia)
